title: Why should the sum of the probabilities in a probability distribution always equal 1? - Quora

response.answer_text: One textbook I used calls it the “something has to happen” rule. A probability of 1 represents certainty, and we’re certain something happened, so if we add up all disjoint possibilities, it should equal certainty. Suppose your probability distribution added to 0.8. If the probability that your value is less than n is 0.25, then the probability that your value is greater than n is 0.55. This means that in 20% of instances we expect the value to be neither less than or greater than n. That doesn’t make sense in most situations. Similarly, suppose your probability distribution adds to 1.2. If the probability that your value is less than n is 0.25, then the probability that the value is greater than n is 0.95. That means that in 20% of instances, we expect the value to be both less than n and greater than n. Again. That doesn’t really make sense. So again, all the possibilities add up to complete certainty.

Because it is a defining property of a probability… If you reject it, then what you are left with is a measure, which is actually still very useful in mathematics !  A measure [math]\mu[/math] on a (measureable) set [math]E[/math] is a function which domain is [math]\mathcal{P}(E)[/math] (the powerset of [math]E[/math], i.e. the set of its parts) and which codomain is included [math]\mathbb{R}_+[/math], the positive real line. So it has positive values. Furthermore : [math]\mu(\varnothing) = 0[/math][math]\mu[/math] is sigma-additive, i.e. if [math]X_n[/math] is a collection of mutually disjoint subsets of [math]E[/math], then [math]\mu\left(\bigcup\limits_{n} X_n\right) = \sum\limits_{n} \mu(X_n)[/math]If you add to that the condition : [math]\mu(E) = 1[/math] then you have defined a probability measure on [math]E[/math].
